segment.source: description: Uniquely identifies elements that are created and referenced as resources, and which exist within a ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: description: Uniquely identifies elements that are created and referenced as resources, and which exist within a ResourceDictionary.

segment.target: title: x:Key attribute'

segment.source: x:Key attribute
segment.target: x:Key attribute

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Uniquely identifies elements that are created and referenced as resources, and which exist within a ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: Uniquely identifies elements that are created and referenced as resources, and which exist within a ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML attribute usage (implicit ResourceDictionary)
segment.target: XAML attribute usage (implicit ResourceDictionary)

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: object
segment.target: object

segment.source: Any object that is shareable.
segment.target: Any object that is shareable.

segment.source: See ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: See ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.

segment.source: stringKeyValue
segment.target: stringKeyValue

segment.source: A true string used as a key, which must conform to the XamlName> grammar.
segment.target: A true string used as a key, which must conform to the XamlName> grammar.

segment.source: See "XamlName grammar" below.
segment.target: See "XamlName grammar" below.

segment.source: XamlName grammar
segment.target: XamlName grammar

segment.source: The following is the normative grammar for a string that is used as a key in the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML implementation:
segment.target: The following is the normative grammar for a string that is used as a key in the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML implementation:

segment.source: Characters are restricted to the lower ASCII range, and more specifically to Roman alphabet uppercase and lowercase letters, digits, and the underscore (\_) character.
segment.target: Characters are restricted to the lower ASCII range, and more specifically to Roman alphabet uppercase and lowercase letters, digits, and the underscore (\_) character.

segment.source: The Unicode character range is not supported.
segment.target: The Unicode character range is not supported.

segment.source: A name cannot begin with a digit.
segment.target: A name cannot begin with a digit.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: Child elements of a ResourceDictionary generally include an x:Key attribute that specifies a unique key value within that dictionary.
segment.target: Child elements of a ResourceDictionary generally include an x:Key attribute that specifies a unique key value within that dictionary.

segment.source: Key uniqueness is enforced at load time by the XAML processor.
segment.target: Key uniqueness is enforced at load time by the XAML processor.

segment.source: Non-unique x:Key values will result in XAML parse exceptions.
segment.target: Non-unique x:Key values will result in XAML parse exceptions.

segment.source: If requested by {StaticResource} markup extension, a non-resolved key will also result in XAML parse exceptions.
segment.target: If requested by {StaticResource} markup extension, a non-resolved key will also result in XAML parse exceptions.

segment.source: x:Key and x:Name are not identical concepts.
segment.target: x:Key and x:Name are not identical concepts.

segment.source: x:Key is used exclusively in resource dictionaries.
segment.target: x:Key is used exclusively in resource dictionaries.

segment.source: x:Name is used for all areas of XAML.
segment.target: x:Name is used for all areas of XAML.

segment.source: A FindName call using a key value will not retrieve a keyed resource.
segment.target: A FindName call using a key value will not retrieve a keyed resource.

segment.source: Note that in the implicit syntax shown, the ResourceDictionary object is implicit in how the XAML processor produces a new object to populate a Resources collection.
segment.target: Note that in the implicit syntax shown, the ResourceDictionary object is implicit in how the XAML processor produces a new object to populate a Resources collection.

segment.source: The code equivalent of specifying x:Key is any operation that uses a key with the underlying ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: The code equivalent of specifying x:Key is any operation that uses a key with the underlying ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: For example, an x:Key applied in markup for a resource is equivalent to the value of the key parameter of Insert when you add the resource to a ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: For example, an x:Key applied in markup for a resource is equivalent to the value of the key parameter of Insert when you add the resource to a ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: An item in a resource dictionary can omit a value for x:Key if it is a targeted Style or ControlTemplate; in each of these cases the implicit key of the resource item is the TargetType value interpreted as a string.
segment.target: An item in a resource dictionary can omit a value for x:Key if it is a targeted Style or ControlTemplate; in each of these cases the implicit key of the resource item is the TargetType value interpreted as a string.

segment.source: For more info, see Quickstart: styling controls and ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: For more info, see Quickstart: styling controls and ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
